head.title: The Nightingale.11 From a letter of Robert Burns to George Thomson, October 29, 1793. First published in James Currie's Works of Robert Burns, 4 vols. (Liverpool: M'Creery, 1800), IV: pp. 140-141.

lg.l: Thou sweetest minstrel of the grove,
That ever tried the plaintive strain
Awake thy tender tale of love,
And sooth a poor forsaken swain.—
Who, though the muses deign to aid
And teach him smoothly to complain;

Yet Delia,22 Alternative name for Artemis or Diana. Citing Tibullus, Maurice Scêve (1510-64) and Samuel Daniel (1562-1619), Alastair Fowler argues that Delia was often used to denote purity. See Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 44. charming, cruel maid,
Is deaf to her forsaken swain.—
All day, with Fashion’s gaudy sons,
In sport she wanders o’er the plain,
Their tales approves, & still she shuns
The notes of her forsaken swain.—
When evening shades obscure the sky,
And bring the solemn hours again,
And sooth a poor forsaken swain.—
